spanishExample: ¡Dile que me tiene que hacer caso!
englishTranslation: Tell him that he has to pay attention to me!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: *¡Give* una vuelta por *the street!*
englishTranslation: Take a walk around the street!

spanishExample: ¿Dices que este no es el camino a la fiesta?
englishTranslation: Are you saying this isn’t the way to the party?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: ¿Qué quieres que le diga? ¡Dile eso!
englishTranslation: What do you want me to tell him? Tell him that!
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: ¿Tuviste la oportunidad de hacerle la pregunta?
englishTranslation: Did you have the chance to ask him the question?

spanishExample: Decía que para entonces sería tarde.
englishTranslation: I was saying that by then it would be late.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)
sería: "would be", "he/she/it would be" (Ser, conditional, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Dicen que *she gave* una vuelta.
englishTranslation: They say that she took a walk.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dijeron que fueron por ese camino de vuelta.
englishTranslation: They said they went along that path again.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dijimos que lo íbamos a hacer de esa manera.
englishTranslation: We said we were going to do it in that manner.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
íbamos: "were going", "we were going" (Ir, imperfect, 1st person plural)

spanishExample: Dime si quieres mi ayuda.
englishTranslation: Tell me if you want my help.

spanishExample: En ese caso, lo que dijiste no estuvo bien.
englishTranslation: In that case, what you said wasn’t right.
vocabIncluded: "bien": adverb meaning "well", "fine", and a variety of other positive things
"lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases

spanishExample: Les tienes que hacer caso a tus padres hoy.
englishTranslation: You have to obey your parents today.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Me dijo que le tenía que hacer caso.
englishTranslation: She told me that I had to pay her attention.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: No quiero que me lo digan de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I don’t want them to tell it to me again.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")

spanishExample: No tenemos que hacerlo de nuevo.
englishTranslation: We don’t have to do it anew.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Para entonces, lo voy a tener que decir.
englishTranslation: By then, I am going to have to say it.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Para entonces, lo habrá dicho de nuevo.
englishTranslation: By then, she will have said it anew.
vocabIncluded: habrá: "will have", "he/she/it will have" before a participle (Haber, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Queremos tu ayuda con este caso.
englishTranslation: We want your help with this case.

spanishExample: Si esa es tu pregunta, entonces no lo vamos a hacer.
englishTranslation: If that’s your question, then we’re not going to do it.
vocabIncluded: using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Te decía que tuve esa oportunidad.
englishTranslation: I was telling you that I had that chance.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Te estoy diciendo que ella está de vuelta.
englishTranslation: I’m telling you that she is present again.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tenemos que *find* otra manera de hacerlo.
englishTranslation: We have to find another manner of doing it.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Tienes que decirle la verdad o ella se la dirá.
englishTranslation: You have to tell him the truth or she will tell him it.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
dirá: "will say", "he/she/it will say" (Decir, future, 3rd person)
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation
